Hydrogenolysis of lignin to produce valuable aromatic chemicals under mild conditions can effectively realize the value-added utilization of lignin. In this work, catalytic transfer hydrogenolysis (CTH) of dealkaline lignin (DL) over Ni0.5Co1.5Al catalyst was studied for the production of phenolic compounds, and the reaction mechanism was elucidated through the reaction of 2-phenoxy-1-phenylethanol (PPE) in deuterated isopropanol (CD3CD(OD)CD3) and D2. Moreover, we investigated the CTH behaviors of various lignin including organic solvents lignin in birch (OL), acidic solvents lignin in birch (AL) and birch powder (BW) to explore the suitability of the Ni0.5Co1.5Al catalyst. The results showed that Ni0.5Co1.5Al was able to catalyze the hydrogenolysis of various lignin into phenolic monomers using isopropanol as an in-situ hydrogen source. Under optimized conditions, the hydrogenolysis of DL over Ni0.5Co1.5Al achieved 43.30 wt% lignin oil yield. The experimental results of isotope labeling experiments exhibited that the active hydrogen generated by isopropanol is used for the cleavage of C-O bonds, and the electronic interactions between Ni and Co promotes the C-O bonds breaking. Isopropanol can not only be a hydrogen donor, but also act as a reaction solvent to stabilize intermediates and enhance the yield of phenolic compounds in the lignin CTH process. Graphical abstract Image, graphical abstract Keywords Lignin NiCoAl catalyst Hydrogenolysis Isopropanol Phenolic compounds Data availability No data was used for the research described in the article. 1 Introduction Nowadays, the vast majority of chemicals and fuels are produced from fossil resources [1]. With the issues such as nonrenewable and increasing scarcity of fossil resources, developing renewable resources has become a focus of research [2,3]. Lignin is the only naturally occurring aromatic biopolymer, consisting mainly of guaiacyl (G), syringyl (S)- and p-hydroxyphenyl (H) units, which can be used as a supplement for the production of fossil-derived chemical products [4–6]. However, owing to the structural intricacy and carbon-based inert property, lignin is generally viewed as a solid waste for power generation in current practice, and only about 2 % of lignin is used for producing value-added chemicals [3]. With the development of biofuel technology, the amount of lignin will be bound to grow rapidly [7]. Therefore, it is of great significance to develop efficient depolymerization processes for lignin utilization by breaking the C-O bonds in lignin. Many approaches have been employed to convert lignin into small molecular compounds, such as pyrolysis [8], hydrogenolysis [9,10], oxidation [11], and tandem strategies [12–14], etc. Among these strategies, hydrogenolysis has attracted much attention because it can achieve highly selective production of mono-phenolic compounds under milder conditions. Kuznetsov et al. [15] studied the catalytic hydrogenolysis of poplar lignin over Ru/C, Pt/ZrO2 and NiCuMo/SiO2 catalysts under 250 ℃, 9.0 MPa H2 with supercritical ethanol. The yield of alkyl substituted phenols (mainly propyl eugenol and propyl guaiacol) were significantly increased under the action of catalysts, but excessive hydrogen pressure leads to further hydrogenation of aromatic compounds. Zhou et al. [16] used non-noble metal catalyst NiCo/C to catalyze the enzymatic hydrolysis lignin with a yield of 20.8 wt% of the monomeric product at 260 ℃ and 3.0 MPa H2. Zeng et al. [17] reported the influence of the structural properties of the Fe-Pd/HZSM-5 catalyst on the catalytic hydrocracking of sugarcane bagasse lignin for the preparation of aromatic monomers. Under the optimal reaction conditions of 1.0 MPa H2 and 320 ℃ in ethanol-water mixed solvent, the yield of aromatic monomers was 27.92 %. It must be pointed out that hydrogenolysis process is usually conducted with high pressure hydrogen, resulting in high cost and undesired hydrogenation of benzene ring. Additionally, hydrogen is mainly produced from fossil fuels and its use will increase the carbon footprint [18–20]. Thus, it is desirable to avoid the employment of high-pressure hydrogen for enhancing the product selectivity and overall efficiency of lignin hydrogenolysis. Catalytic transfer hydrogenolysis (CTH) using organic solvents (methanol, ethanol, formic acid, etc.) as hydrogen donors has been proved to be a promising way for C-O bonds cleavage and lignin depolymerization [21–23]. Among various organic hydrogen donors, isopropanol has a strong hydrogen supply capacity and higher reactivity, thus it is widely used in the CTH of lignin [24]. Hua et al. [25] demonstrated that using isopropanol as a hydrogen source, Ru/C and Ru/hydroxyapatite catalysts can effectively catalyze aromatic ether bonds cleavage in various lignin-derived compounds. Wang et al. [26] studied the hydrogenolysis of Enzymatic hydrolysis lignin (EHL) over Ni-Ru/Al2O3 catalyst using isopropanol as the reaction solvent without additional hydrogen. The 2D Heteronuclear Single Quantum Coherence Nuclear Magnetic Resonance Spectroscopy (2D HSQC NMR) analysis verified that Ni-Ru/Al2O3 catalyst was high activity for C-O bonds cleavage. Paone et al. [27] showed that the Pd/Fe3O4 catalyst was able to catalyze the hydrogenolysis of benzyl phenyl ether into phenol and toluene completely at 240 ℃ with isopropanol as the hydrogen donor. Zeng et al. [28] used different bimetallic (Ru, Pd and Pt) catalysts loaded on various carriers (activated carbon, γ-Al2O3, TiO2, HZSM-5) to improve the hydrogenolysis process of sulfated lignin using isopropanol as in-situ hydrogen source. Many studies have shown that isopropanol as the hydrogen source promoted the CTH of lignin, but the CTH process usually needed the involvement of precious metals as active components of catalysts. Meanwhile, the hydrogen supply mechanism of isopropanol in the CTH process and the cleavage mechanism of the C-O bonds in lignin are still ambiguous, which makes the process optimization of lignin hydrogenolysis difficult. In our previous studies [29], we found that the Ni0.5Co1.5Al catalyst can effectively cleave the C-O bonds via the CTH in different lignin model compounds. However, since the structure of lignin is far more complex than those of model compounds, it is necessary to investigate the suitability of the Ni0.5Co1.5Al catalyst on transfer hydrogenolysis of lignin. Herein, in-situ hydrogenolysis of dealkaline lignin (DL), organic solvents lignin in birch (OL), acidic solvents lignin in birch (AL) and birch powder was investigated in isopropanol over Ni0.5Co1.5Al catalyst. Firstly, the effects of reaction conditions on lignin oil yield during DL hydrogenolysis was studied. The products of lignin CTH were analyzed by GC–MS, GPC, FTIR, 2D HSQC NMR and Orbitrap-MS. Then, the CTH process of 2-phenoxy-1-phenylethanol (PPE) was studied by deuterated isopropanol (CD3CD(OD)CD3) and D2 isotope labeling method, and the CTH pathway of lignin was discussed in combination with the results of lignin model compounds. These results showed that lignin hydrogenolysis balance can be promoted by product consumption in situ hydrogenolysis reaction systems, thus obtaining high lignin conversion and phenolic monomer yields. 2 Materials and methods 2.1 Materials All reagents used in this work are of analytical purity without further purification. 2-phenoxy-1-phenylethanol and 2,2,6,6-Tetramethylpiperidinooxy (TEMPO) were obtained from Aladdin Reagents (Shanghai, China) Co. 2-propanol-D8 was obtained from Maclean's Reagents (Shanghai, China) Co. 1,4-dioxane, HCl, formic acid, acetic acid ethanol and isopropanol were purchased from Xilong Chemical Co., Ltd. and used as supplied. Birch wood (BW) was from a manufacturer in Zhejiang province, China, and dealkaline lignin (DL) was purchased from Tokyo Chemical Industry Co., Ltd. 2.2 Extraction of lignin from birch wood 2.2.1 Separation of organic solvents lignin in birch (OL) Birch organic solvent lignin (OL) was extracted according to the reported work [30]. 60 g of 40 mesh birch wood, 430 mL of 1,4-dioxane, and 50 mL of HCl solution (2 mol·L−1) were added to a flask. The mixture was refluxed at 110 ℃ in a nitrogen atmosphere for 90 min and cooled to room temperature. After filtration, the filtrate was combined and concentrated after washing with 1,4-dioxane three times. Then the concentrate was added to 2 L water to get the residue, which was filtered and washed. The crude dry birch lignin yield was 17.3 wt% (10.37 g). Next, 60 mL of a mixture of acetone and water (v:v = 9:1) was added to the residue and stirred for 1 h. After that, 1.5 L of ice water was added to the mixed system, and the precipitate was collected by filtrate and dried at 60 ℃. The dried lignin sample was registered as organic solvent lignin (OL). The yield of OL was 10.7 wt % (6.42 g). 2.2.2 Separation of acidic solvents lignin in birch (AL) According to previous reports [31,32], 3 g of 40 mesh dried birch wood, 30 mL formic acid and acetic acid mixed solution (v:v = 4:5) and 0.5 mL of HCl were added to a 100 mL of round bottom flask. The mixture was first heated to 91 ℃ and maintained at that temperature for 4 h. After cooling to room temperature, 10 times the volume of water was added to precipitate, then centrifuged and washed with water to neutral. The crude birch lignin yield was 14.3 wt% (0.43 g). The obtained crude birch lignin was dissolved in a mixed solvent of 1,4-dioxane/ethanol (v:v = 8:2), centrifuged to remove the residue, and the supernatant was added to an equal volume of ether/petroleum ether mixture (Scheme 1 ). The residue was dried in a vacuum drying oven at 60 ℃ to obtain acid-extracted birch lignin (AL). The yield of AL was 9.3 wt% (0.28 g). 2.3 CTH of lignin and BW The detailed catalyst preparation process and characterization analysis have been carried out in depth, which can be inferred from our previous work [29]. Catalytic hydrogenolysis of lignin was carried out in a 100 mL autoclave reactor. In a typical experiment, substrate (100 mg), catalyst (20 mg), and isopropanol (25 mL) were added into the autoclave. After purging with high-purity nitrogen gas three times and pressurizing to 1.0 MPa N2, the reactor was heated to the desired temperature at 200 r/min stirring speed and kept for a certain time. Then, the reactor was cooled to room temperature, the liquid product was separated through a sand core filtration device. All solvents in the liquid product were removed by vacuum rotary evaporation, and the substance left after rotary evaporation was considered to be lignin oil (Scheme 2 ). 2.4 Product analysis The lignin oil was identified using an Agilent 7890A-5975C GC–MS instrument equipped with an HP-5 capillary column (60 m × 250 μm × 0.25 μm). High-purity helium gas was used as the carrier gas, and the split ratio was set at 50 : 1 with an inlet temperature of 60 ℃. The macromolecular compounds obtained after the hydrogenolysis of lignin were analyzed by a quadrupole/Orbitrap MS (Q-Exactive, Thermo Fisher Co., USA). The sample was analyzed with an atmospheric pressure chemical ionization (APCI) source in Q-Exactive positive ion mode. The discharge current was selected at 4.0 µA, the capillary temperature was set at 275 ℃, and the nebulization temperature was chosen as 300 ℃. The ion scanning scope was 100–600 m/z, and the resolution as 140,000. The sheath gas and auxiliary gas were high-purity nitrogen (≥99.999 %), and the flow rates were 20 and 10 arb, respectively. The data obtained by Orbitrap MS were analyzed by Xcalibur Roadmap Software Data Analysis 3.0 software from Thermo Fisher. The signal-to-noise ratio for peak detection was 3, and the mass tolerance of the molecular formula was less than 3 ppm. The molecular formula was limited to a maximum of 50 C, 100 H, 6 O and 4 N atoms. Prominence GPC system developed by Shimadzu detected the molecular weight distribution of lignin residue. The dried lignin residue was dissolved in N, N-dimethylformamide (m: m = 1: 2) and filtered with a 0.45 μm organic filter after a period of static analysis. The structures of lignin and lignin oil were analyzed by Bruker Ascend TM 400 two-dimensional nuclear magnetic resonance (2D NMR). The DMSO-d6 solution was used to dissolve the sample, and the heterogeneous single quantum coherence spectroscopy (HSQC) was used to collect the signal of the program. Fourier transform infrared (FTIR) spectroscopy was used to detect the distribution of functional groups after lignin hydrogenolysis. In the transmission mode, the Nicolet Magna 560 FTIR spectrometer was measured using a mercury cadmium telluride (MCT) detector. The samples were mixed and ground with KBr, then pressed into tablets. The spectra were collected from 650 to 4000 cm−1 with 32 scans. The yields of reaction residue and lignin oil were calculated according to the following equations: (1) S i (%) = Y i / Y total ×100 (%) (2) Y (wt%) lignin oil = mass of lignin oil / mass of lignin ×100 (%) (3) Y (wt%) residue = mass of solid products-mass of catalyst / mass of lignin ×100 (%) (4) Conversion = moles of substrate reacted / total moles of substrate × 100 (%) Where S i means the selectivity of product i 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Catalytic hydrogenolysis of DL Previous studies [15,21] indicated that reaction temperature and time are the two essential factors for lignin hydrogenolysis. Therefore, the optimized Ni0.5Co1.5Al catalyst was used to study the products distribution after DL hydrogenolysis at different reaction temperatures (240–300 ℃) and reaction times (4–10 h). As shown in Fig. 1 a, the yields of lignin oil increased significantly with reaction temperature rising. This may be due to the fact that the hydrogenolysis reaction is endothermic process, and the high temperatures favor the catalytic hydrogenolysis of DL by enhancing the cleavage of the C-O bonds, thereby significantly increasing the yield of lignin oil. In addition, the increase of reaction temperature enhances the hydrogen transfer performance of isopropanol, thus promoting the depolymerization of lignin. Depolymerization at temperature above 300 ℃ was not investigated because the limit of the reactor in present work. Despite all this, GC–MS can detect a variety of phenolic compounds at the reaction temperature of 300 ℃, as revealed by 2D HSQC NMR below, indicating that the C-O bonds can be effectively broken under such temperature. Fig. 1b showed the effect of reaction time on the hydrogenolysis of DL at 300 ℃. It was observed that the lignin oil yield was positively correlated with the holding time, and the highest lignin oil yield of 43.30 wt% was obtained at 8 h. With the extension of reaction time to 10 h, the yield of lignin oil was slightly decreased. It is possible that prolongation of reaction time resulting in the condensation of monomer fragments and more complex oligomer products. Therefore, excessively long reaction time does not always have a positive impact on DL hydrogenolysis. It is worth noting that the lignin oil yield increased significantly after the introduction of the catalyst under the same reaction conditions, indicating that the Ni0.5Co1.5Al catalyst can effectively promote lignin depolymerization. Furthermore, the yield of lignin oil was reduced under hydrogen atmosphere (Table S1), resulting from the competitive adsorption of hydrogen, isopropanol and substrate on the catalyst active sites, which agreed with the results obtained from the CTH of lignin model compounds [29]. As shown in Fig. 2 , the compounds in lignin oil are mainly phenolic compounds, together with small amounts of aromatic ethers, aromatic ketones and aromatic aldehydes. In Fig. 2a, the relative content of phenolic compounds, aromatic ether compounds and aromatic ketone compounds decreased, which may be attributed to the elimination of unstable intermediates from lignin to produce active benzyl carbon cations or olefins. These reactive compounds that have not been converted in time, especially phenols may undergo recondensation reactions, resulting in the formation of oligomers products [33]. As shown in Table S4 and Table S6, Olefinic structural products such as 3-allylguaiacol and 2-methoxy-4-vinyphenol were detected in the products. Although there is no clear explanation about the polymerization mechanisms of lignin intermediates (free radicals or cations), previous studies have reported that styrene undergoes thermal polymerization at a certain temperature. Hence, based on the products distributions of lignin oil, it can be speculated that the intermediates generated from the hydrogenolysis of lignin may undergo the condensation reactions (Scheme 3 ). For the Cα-OH type, the vinyl condensation can also be dehydrated to a Cα=Cβ structure. The formation of dimer 3 indicated that the quinone formamide intermediate undergoes the nucleophilic addition of creosote, and this condensation reaction competes with the formation of Cα=Cβ and subsequent vinyl coupling [34]. For the reaction pathway b, dimers 4 and 5 are the coupling products between Cα=Cβ. Rizzi et al. [35] compared the 1H NMR spectra with the reported data, according to the large coupling constant (16.0 Hz) of the two adjacent protons attached to the double bond in the dimer, and they confirmed that dimer 4 is a coupling product of Cα and Cβ. Chen et al. [36] also indicated that styrene undergoes thermal polymerization and self-initiated condensation under similar reaction conditions. The interunit C-C bonds obtained from these recondensation reactions have high bond energy, and are difficult to be cleaved. When the temperature rose to 300 ℃, the relative content of phenolic compounds decreased to 75.27 %, while the production of lignin oil yield increased significantly. These results indicated that the condensation reactions of aromatic compounds will result in lower relative content of phenolic compounds in the products. Fig. 2b exhibited the effect of reaction time on the distribution of lignin oil products. With the elevation of reaction time, the yield of lignin oil first increased and then decreased. When the reaction time extended to 8 h, the yield of DL lignin oil products increased to 43.30 wt%, and the relative content of phenols was 79.29 %. According to previous studies [21,28,37], the interactions between alcohol solvents and polar groups of lignin can enhance the solubility of lignin, which facilitates the contact of the substrate with the catalyst. Moreover, the free radicals and carbon ions formed by isopropanol self-conversion are involved in the reaction, which promotes the breaking of the bonds in lignin and stabilizes the reactive intermediates [38]. Therefore, isopropanol as a hydrogen source can promote the lignin hydrogenolysis process. Notably, 2-isopropoxyphenol was detected in the products, and its relative content increased with reaction time. This may be caused by alcoholysis reactions formed between isopropanol and phenols. As the reaction time continued to elongate, the lignin oil yield and monomer selectivity declined significantly, and the kinds of intermediates generated from lignin hydrogenolysis became more diverse, and other compounds such as 2-methyl-2-hexanol, 3-octanol and trans-1,2-cyclohexanediol appeared in the products (Table S5 and Table S7). When the reaction time was extended to 10 h, the relative content of phenolic compounds decreased to 72.91 %, while the yield of DL lignin oil products decreased to 41.76 %, The decrease of lignin oil yield is probably due to the condensation and repolymerization reactions between the unstable fragments of lignin and the original lignin to form lignin residues [39]. Therefore, excessively long reaction times eventually lead to condensation of the products, producing complex macromolecular compounds with more complex structures and higher bond energies. 3.2 Characterization of products 3.2.1 GPC analysis The hydrogenolysis and repolymerization reactions of DL and their effect on molecular weight changes in the depolymerized products were studied via GPC analysis under various reaction conditions (Fig. S2). The results for the weight-average molecular weight (Mw), number-average molecular weight (Mn), and polydispersity index (PDI) of DL hydrogenolysis under different reaction conditions are presented in Table 1 . The addition of the catalyst resulted in decreased Mw and Mn values of the lignin residual products compared to non-catalyzed DL hydrogenolysis. Under a reaction temperature of 300 ℃, the depolymerized products showed a similar trend with extended reaction time, indicating that macromolecules in DL transformed into small molecules (monomers and oligomers). It confirms that the Ni0.5Co1.5Al catalyst is effectively catalyzed DL hydrogenolysis using isopropanol as solvent under a nitrogen atmosphere. Under the optimal reaction conditions of 300 ℃ and 8 h, the average weight molecular (Mw) of lignin residue was significantly reduced, indicating that more monomer compounds could be obtained by appropriately prolonging the reaction time. 3.2.2 2D HSQC NMR analysis To further investigate the structural changes of lignin after hydrogenolysis, 2D HSQC NMR was used to characterize the lignin oil products. The chemical shift assignment of identified peaks in HSQC is determined by comparison with literatures, standards or in combination with HMBC correlation [40]. The signal region of 2D HSQC NMR spectrum is mainly divided into aliphatic side-chain region (δC/δH=50–90/2.5–5.0 ppm) and aromatic region (δC/δH=100–150/6.5–8.0 ppm) (Fig. 3 ) [15,22,26]. In general, the lignin structure mainly contains the β-O-4 (A), β-5 (B) and β-β (C) unit structures. It is noteworthy that the signals of δc/δH = 60.0/3.4 ppm and δC/δH = 70.7/3.8 ppm were detected in the spectra of the catalytic DL hydrogenolysis products, which were associated with Aγ/Hγ and Cγ/Hγ of the β-O-4 and β-β substructures, respectively. This may be attributed to the fact that more stable C-C bonds still exist in lignin-derived oligomers (Table S2). Compared with the non-catalytic lignin oil products, the intensity of signal peaks of S2,6 (δC/δH=106.2/6.6 ppm), G2 (δC/δH=110.8/6.8 ppm), G5 (δC/δH=114.9/6.7 ppm) and G6 (δC/δH=119.0/6.8 ppm) increased significantly after the introduction of the catalyst, indicating that the catalyzed lignin produced a rich variety of phenolic compounds, which is consistent with the GC–MS analysis. Signal peaks of methoxy (–OCH3) at δC/δH=56.2/3.75 ppm are all present in Fig. 3, indicating that the products are all rich in ether bonding groups after depolymerization. Ni0.5Co1.5Al catalyst can selectively cleave the C-O bonds in dimers, but it has limited ability to cleave the C-O bonds in the monomer products containing methoxy (Table S3). Therefore, the products rich in ether bond groups are mainly monomer compounds, such as phenylethyl ether, 1,2-dimethoxybenzene, 1,2,3-trimethoxybenzene, 2,5-dimethoxyethylbenzene, etc. To summarize the above, the Ni0.5Co1.5Al catalyst can effectively catalyst the C-O bonds breaking between lignin structural units and obtain high-value phenolic compounds. 3.2.3 FTIR analysis FT-IR spectroscopy was used to study the structural changes of the lignin hydrogenolysis products (Fig. 4 ). It can be observed that after introducing the catalyst, the FT-IR spectra changed significantly, and the intensities of the characteristic peaks at different positions were enhanced significantly (Fig. 4a). The peak at 3377 cm−1 ascribed to the O-H stretching vibration of phenolic hydroxyl groups suggested the presence of phenolics hydroxyl groups after lignin hydrogenolysis. Moreover, the broadening and peak shift of the O-H bond stretching vibration peak associated with phenols demonstrated that the phenolic compounds increased and the types are diversified after introducing the catalyst. The C-H stretching peaks corresponding to methyl and methylene at 2973 cm−1 changed significantly, indicating that methylation reaction occurred during hydrogenolysis. The signal peak at 1718 cm−1 demonstrated the presence of the carbonyl group. The strong absorption peaks at 1605, 1500 and 1468 cm−1 were attributed to the benzene ring. The aromatic skeleton in the structure of lignin oil indicated that the original aromatic structure was retained in the hydrogenolysis products of lignin. The peaks at 818 cm−1 and 747 cm−1 were the C-O substituent groups of the benzene ring, the increase in peak intensity indicates an increase in the content of aromatic ring species [41]. Compared with the non-catalytic reaction, the increase in the 818 cm−1 and 747 cm−1 peaks intensity after introduction with Ni0.5Co1.5Al catalyst means an increase in the content of aromatic ring compounds. The FTIR results showed that the absorption peaks of the lignin products changed significantly after the introduction of the catalyst, indicating that the Ni0.5Co1.5Al can effectively depolymerize lignin. 3.2.4 Orbitrap-MS analysis As shown in Fig. S3, the peak positions of Orbitrap-MS mass spectra for the lignin oil were mainly in the range of 100–300 Da. The overall shift in the charge-to-mass ratio of the lignin oil products towards the lower value region after the introduction of the catalyst, indicated that Ni0.5Co1.5Al catalyzed hydrogenolysis of lignin producing more low molecular weight compounds. Fig. 5 was the DBE and carbon number diagram of lignin oil product. The heteroatom-containing compounds with characteristic ring structures (CcHhNnOo) usually exhibits a specific DBE value, which can be deduced from the plot of DBE versus carbon number. DBE represents the number of double bonds plus the number of rings in a given formula, which can be calculated by the previous reported equation ( DBE = c − h 2 + n 2 + 1 ) [42,43]. From the diagram, it can be seen that the DBE signal is mainly distributed in the range of 2–8, and the carbon number is distributed in the range of 6–15, corresponding to the aromatic structure containing oxygen atoms in the form of hydroxyl, methoxy, carboxyl or ester groups. Fig. S4 showed the isoabundance diagram of DBE and the carbon number of O1-O4 compounds. The O2 and O3 species with DBE≥4 may be some compounds with guaiacol and eugenol as the parent structure. The species with DBE values of 4–7, 8–11 and 12–14 should correspond to monomer, dimer and trimer phenols, respectively [43,44]. The O4-O6 species with DBE≥8 may be a random combination of benzene ring, phenol, guaiacol and eugenol [45]. More O2 and O3 species with DBE≥4 were detected in the liquid products after lignin catalytic hydrogenolysis, which corresponded to the rise in the types of aromatic compounds, corresponding to the increase in the content of mono-phenolic compounds detected by GC–MS. 3.3 CTH of lignin model compounds in deuterated isopropanol In order to understand the transfer hydrogenolysis pathway of lignin catalyzed by Ni0.5Co1.5Al, 2-phenoxy-1-phenylethanol (PPE) was chosen as a typical model compound to be explored. As shown in Scheme 4 , there are different products obtained by PPE with isopropanol and deuterated isopropanol (CD3CD(OD)CD3) under H2 and N2 atmospheres (Fig. S5). Compared with the reaction system with isopropanol as solvent, the CTH reaction of PPE in deuterated isopropanol became slower owing to the isotope effect. There were three main products in the hydrogen atmosphere, namely ethylbenzene, cyclohexanol and phenol, while the main components in the nitrogen atmosphere were ethylbenzene and cyclohexanol, and only trace amounts of phenol and 1-phenylethanol were detected. As listed in Table S1, the conversion of PPE in H2 atmosphere was lower than that in N2 atmosphere. It was observed that the introduction of H2 will lead to the decrease in PPE conversion, which may be caused by the competitive adsorption of H2 on the active sites of the catalyst [46,47]. To further verify the source of active hydrogen, the CTH of PPE was investigated in D2 atmosphere using isopropanol as reaction solvent. As expected, no D atoms were identified in the main products (Fig. S5), indicating the active hydrogen involved in the hydrogenolysis reaction is mainly derived from isopropanol rather than D2. In Fig. 6 , the signal peak of 2-phenoxyethylbenzene at m/z = 198 in the product was significantly increased to m/z = 199 using deuterated isopropanol as a reaction solvent, indicating that there is a direct cleavage of the Cα-OH bond during the hydrogenolysis of PPE, and the active hydrogen species for the dissociation of the Cα-OH bond are derived from the solvent rather than H2. In addition, the different mass shifts of ethylbenzene, phenol and 1-phenylethanol can be detected in PPE after a deuterated isopropanol reaction under N2 and H2 atmosphere. The mass spectrum showed that deuterated isopropanol will generate Acetone-D6 after the reaction, which demonstrates that the mixed hydrogen source will participate in the hydrogenation of the intermediate products, and the H/D exchange will occur on the benzene ring during the CTH reaction. The cleavage of the C-O bonds during the CTH of lignin is achieved by the attack of the active hydrogen intermediate. Cheng et al. [48,49] reported that isopropanol can be used for C-O bonds cleavage by releasing free radical hydrogen. Therefore, the free radical trapping agent TEMPO was selected to study the form of active hydrogen species produced by isopropanol. As shown in Fig. S6, PPE was converted into ethylbenzene, cyclohexanol and others without TEMPO. However, the addition of TEMPO into the reaction system restricted the conversion of PPE, indicating that TEMPO had a strong inhibitory effect on the hydrogenolysis reaction of PPE. In other words, the CTH of PPE catalyzed by Ni0.5Co1.5Al was a free radical process. During the hydrogenolysis reaction, isopropanol was adsorbed on the Ni-Co alloy site to produce active hydrogen, while the acidic sites on Ni0.5Co1.5Al catalyze the dehydration of PPE, resulting in the cleavage of Cα-OH to form 2-phenoxyethylbenzene. Furthermore, the electron transfer from Ni to Co weakens the C-O bond in PPE, leading to the C-O bonds cleavage in PPE. 3.4 Catalytic hydrogenolysis of Various lignin and BW To investigate the suitability of Ni0.5Co1.5Al catalysts in lignin hydrogenolysis reactions, other typical lignocellulosic biomasses were included in the extended hydrogenolysis reactions. The major monophenols of lignin oil products from various lignin hydrogenolysis are listed in Table 2 and Fig. S7. Hardwood lignin is usually composed of a large number of syringyl (S) units, typically has more C-O bonds, particularly β-O-4 bonds [31]. Birch is a typical hardwood whose lignin is primarily comprised of guaiacol (G) and syringyl (S) units. Therefore, we investigated the hydrogenolysis reaction of birch lignin extracted by different methods. Based on Table 2, it can be seen that Ni0.5Co1.5Al functions as a catalyst to promote the breaking of C-O bonds between lignin structure units. Isopropanol as a solvent and hydrogen donor can stabilize intermediates and release active hydrogen, which is consistent with the hydrogenolysis process of lignin model compounds. In addition, the hydrogenolysis products of OL and AL are enriched with phenolic compounds, which may be attributed to the higher content of ether bonds in the lignin from birch raw materials. Other factors such as the extraction method and the properties of the lignin may also contribute to the difference in the yield of phenolic compounds between extracted lignin and DL [50]. Although the main products distribution of OL and AL are similar after hydrogenolysis, the oil yield of AL (17.58 wt%) is lower than that of OL (20.10 wt%) (Fig. S8). This may be due to the fact that extracting lignin with organic solvents can better preserve the structure of lignin (Fig. S9). However, acid extraction of lignin leads to the repolymerization of interunit C-C bonds, resulting in a more complex lignin structure which is difficult to further upgrade [31]. In addition, lignin from hardwood typically contains more β-O-4 linkages, which results in a higher yield of monophenols [51]. Mild pretreatment methods can preserve more β-O-4 linkages in lignin and thus enhance the production of monophenols [52]. OL is more susceptible to hydrogenolysis due to its high degree of unsaturation and low molecular weight. Furthermore, the quantity of phenolic compounds during lignin hydrogenolysis is significantly influenced by the condensed structures and short side chains in lignin. 3.5 Lignin CTH mechanism According to the products distribution of lignin CTH and hydrogenolysis mechanism of model compounds catalyzed by Ni0.5Co1.5Al, the possible reaction path of lignin hydrogenolysis process can be inferred. From the results of catalysts characterization in our previous work [29], Ni0.5Co1.5Al catalyst has Ni-Co alloy sites and acidic sites. It has been reported that the Ni-Co alloy has a better affinity for oxygen and can bind to the hydroxyl group (-OH) in isopropanol at a much lower bond dissociation energy to produce active hydrogen. The presence of acidic sites on Ni0.5Co1.5Al contributes to the dehydration reaction of Cα-OH, which leads to the breakage of Cα-OH bonds. In addition, the electron transfer between Ni and Co optimizes the electronic structure of the metal active site, promotes the adsorption of active hydrogen and weakens the C-O bonds energy of the substrate. The active hydrogen is combined with the oxygen atom in the ether bonds (C-O) during the reaction, then the C-O bonds are broken over the Ni0.5Co1.5Al catalyst. As shown in Scheme 5 , the three-dimensional composite structure of lignin contains several typical C-O bonds: β-O-4, α-O-4 and 4-O-5. Among them, β-O-4 is rich in C-O ether bonds and has the highest content in natural lignin. In the process of lignin hydrogenolysis, the active hydrogen species generated by isopropanol can effectively adsorb the fragment molecules after lignin depolymerization, and the Ni0.5Co1.5Al catalyze the cleavage of C-O ether bonds to form a series of active phenolic compounds. Due to the complexity of the lignin depolymerization intermediate products, some soluble intermediates in the reaction will be converted into other aromatic compounds, and the intermediates will be repolymerized to form more complex compounds. 4 Conclusions In summary, the Ni0.5Co1.5Al catalyst can effectively catalyze the hydrogenolysis of lignin C-O bonds to generate phenolic compounds, where guaiacol is the main product. The hydrogenolysis experiments of PPE in deuterated isopropanol (CD3CD(OD)CD3), D2 and TEMPO indicated that isopropanol as a hydrogen donor can provide hydrogen radicals during the reaction process and participate in the hydrogenolysis process. Moreover, the Ni0.5Co1.5Al catalyst also exhibited better catalytic performance in AL and OL hydrogenolysis, and the catalyst are generally applicable to a wider range of lignin. This work provides a reference for the selective hydrogenolysis of lignin under mild conditions to produce phenolic monomers. coredata.dc:description: Hydrogenolysis of lignin to produce valuable aromatic chemicals under mild conditions can effectively realize the value-added utilization of lignin. In this work, catalytic transfer hydrogenolysis (CTH) of dealkaline lignin (DL) over Ni0.5Co1.5Al catalyst was studied for the production of phenolic compounds, and the reaction mechanism was elucidated through the reaction of 2-phenoxy-1-phenylethanol (PPE) in deuterated isopropanol (CD3CD(OD)CD3) and D2. Moreover, we investigated the CTH behaviors of various lignin including organic solvents lignin in birch (OL), acidic solvents lignin in birch (AL) and birch powder (BW) to explore the suitability of the Ni0.5Co1.5Al catalyst. The results showed that Ni0.5Co1.5Al was able to catalyze the hydrogenolysis of various lignin into phenolic monomers using isopropanol as an in-situ hydrogen source. Under optimized conditions, the hydrogenolysis of DL over Ni0.5Co1.5Al achieved 43.30 wt% lignin oil yield. The experimental results of isotope labeling experiments exhibited that the active hydrogen generated by isopropanol is used for the cleavage of C-O bonds, and the electronic interactions between Ni and Co promotes the C-O bonds breaking. Isopropanol can not only be a hydrogen donor, but also act as a reaction solvent to stabilize intermediates and enhance the yield of phenolic compounds in the lignin CTH process.
coredata.dc:title: In-situ transfer hydrogenolysis of lignin into phenolic monomers over Ni0.5Co1.5Al catalyst
